Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Story: I was just finishing my shift at the pool when my phone buzzed. It was Jamie, my best friend, sounding frazzled. “Hey, can you hop on a quick video call? I’m drowning in these furniture instructions.” I glanced at the clock—swim lessons would start in half an hour. As I walked past the pool, I noticed the lane rope was snapped, floating uselessly in the water. If I didn’t fix it now, the lessons would be a mess, and the supervisor would definitely have words for me. But Jamie’s voice in my head tugged at me—he’d helped me through so much, and I knew he was counting on me. My hands shook as I weighed the wrench in one hand and my phone in the other, feeling the pressure of being a good friend and a responsible lifeguard at the same time.
